awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Framework for Assessing the Impact of Extreme Heat and Drought on Urban Energy Production and Consumption
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will produce novel, rigorous and integrative methods that will contribute to society's capacity for effectively managing city-scale electricity systems during periods of extreme heat and drought. The modern electric grid, which includes both electricity consumers and producers, faces significant challenges and uncertainties, including increased frequency and intensity of heat waves and droughts. Concurrently, the processes underlying electricity production and consumption are becoming more complex, due in part to advances in electric grid-connected technologies and the demand-side management programs that control them. This research will improve knowledge of city-specific future extreme heat and drought scenarios, as well as quantification of the impact of extreme events under these scenarios on a city's electricity consumption and production. Findings from this research have the potential to significantly impact the way cities and electric utility operators manage electric grids under extreme heat and drought conditions.

This project addresses vital links between climate modeling, consumption and production, and seeks to contribute to the following scientific advancements: 1) development of effective methods for generating refined future extreme heat and drought scenarios utilizing disparate sources of data of varying fidelity, such as historical observations; 2) development of a flexible electricity consumption model integrated with demand-side management strategies using bottom-up energy and demand modeling methods; 3) development of a data-driven stochastic optimization method for robust power-generation decision strategies that considers various sources of uncertainty, including weather and the consumption and production of electricity.

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed a new integrative methodology that offers a framework to be used at the city scale to assess the impacts of extreme heat on the consumption of the modern electricity grid and describes a robust decision-making framework to prepare for extreme weather conditions in order to maintain a high-level power grid reliability. Characterizing spatially- and temporarily-varying localized climate conditions is becoming important in quantifying the city-scale energy consumption. The Weather Research and Forecasting model, coupled with Urban Canopy Model, represents detailed urban ambient characteristics. However, such physics-based numerical models can exhibit a spatially and temporarily heterogeneous discrepancy pattern compared to actual climate conditions possibly due to inappropriate model specifications and/or incorrect choices of model parameters. This project devised a new method that post-calibrates geographically- and temporally-varying discrepancy in an integrative framework. Further, this project analyzed how the demand response program will affect future peak energy consumption when extreme heat events occur.

With the resulting research outcomes, five research papers have been published in peer-reviewed journals and proceedings. Among them, one paper was selected as one of Best Student Paper Finalists in the 2021 IISE Data Analytics & Information Systems subdivision. Moreover, Youngchan Jang completed his dissertation, entitled ?Data science in energy and environmental systems using multiple data sources.? The research findings have been presented in various conferences, including INFORMS, ISERC, and IEEE Conference on Automation Science and Engineering.

Through the development of several methods to model energy use and/or demand at the city scale, the results of this work contribute several types of new models that can be used to estimate energy use and demand of cities, and project use into future years, based on climate model methods and resulting data as input. The combined sets of models can provide an overall framework for how to model city-scale energy use and production, projected into the future under extreme weather scenarios.

This project contributed toward the preparation of a future workforce in the field of energy and sustainability through an array of mechanisms including the integration of under-represented students in the STEM field into energy research and opportunities for students to interact with researchers in different fields such as civil engineering and geological and atmospheric sciences. One participating Ph.D. student joined a research center as a senior researcher, after completing his dissertation successfully.
